titleStmt.title: Severall letters from Col. Gen. Poyntz. Lieu. Gen. Cromwell. [brace] and [brace] Col. Hutchison. Col. Whitt. of the late great victory neere Sherborne in the north, with some other happy successes in the west. Printed according to the originall, together with an order of both Houses for thanksgiving for the same. Die Sabbathi 25. Octob. 1645. Ordered by the Lords assembled in Parliament, that these letters, with the order for the thanksgiving, beforthwith printed and published. Joh. Brown Cler. Parliamentorum.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p:
Severall LETTERS FROM
Col. Gen. Poyntz.
Lieu. Gen. Cromwell. and
Col. Hutchi≈øon.
Col. Whitt.
OF The late great Victory neere Sherborne in the North, with ≈øome other happy ≈øucce≈ø≈øes in the We≈øt.
Printed according to the Originall, together with an Order of both Hou≈øes for Thank≈øgiving for the ≈øame.
ORdered by the Lords a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, That the≈øe Letters, with the Order for the Thank≈øgiving, be forthwith printed and publi≈øhed.
LONDON, Printed for John Wright at the Kings head in the old Bayley. 27 Octob. 1645.

div.head: For his worthy friend Ma≈øter Bedford Scout-Ma≈øter-Generall to the Committee of both Kingdoms.
div.p: OUr news is very joyfull, even the Defeat of a raging Enemy of neer 2000 men under the command of Digby, having taken 1000 Foot of mine neere Ferry-brig, my Hor≈øe under the command of Colonell Copley fell ≈øuddenly upon them, and not onely relea≈øed the Foot, but God gave us an ab≈øolute Victory, as the Li≈øt inclo≈øed will manife≈øt. There is not above two or three hundred of them left together, who are fled towards Skipton, eight hundred of mine pur≈øuing of them: ≈øo that I am retreating to block up the North ≈øide of Newarke, and ≈øent two Regiments to Colonell Ro≈ø≈øiter to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him in the blocking up the South≈øide till I receive further Orders from the Honourable Committee of both Kingdoms. There is no con≈øiderable Enemy for me to follow. The King being at Newarke, and the Garri≈øon cleared of mo≈øt of their Hor≈øe, it is conceived a very ≈øea≈øonable time to block up the ≈øame. I want onely their commands. You ≈øhall further heare from me by the next that offers ≈øo much happine≈ø≈øe to

closer.signed: Your friend to ≈øerve you, Sednham Poyntz.

div.head: For the Honourable Colonell Thornhigh at the Kings head in the Strand the≈øe, with my humble ≈øervice.
div.p: SInce your departure hence Partees have been ≈øent out every night, but the Enemy have drawne into their Garri≈øons continually, that nothing could be attempted; only on Fryday morning la≈øt, Corporall Crofts, who is one of my Corporals, with 20 hor≈øe of Captaine Pendocks and mine did fall into Bridgeford ≈øuper mount, whether the Queens Regiment were newly come, and all mounted; they charged through them, routed the whole Regiment, killed eight be≈øides what were wounded and brought off, 16 pri≈øoners, 28 hor≈øe, without lo≈ø≈øe of one man. And on Saturday following, my Lieutenant, with 42 men going to ≈øecure the market, fell into Langar, where the Earle of Northamptons Regiments were drawing out to a Rendezvouz, being about 200 hor≈øe: Thirty of our men charged about 80. of them, and routed them, and falling into the Towne with them they killed betwixt twenty and thirty, and a Captaine: they tooke a Major, nine others, and 27 Hor≈øe, without lo≈ø≈øe of one man. I de≈øire that God may have the prai≈øe of all, for he is worthy. On Sunday Captaine Pendock and my Lieutenant, with 150 Hor≈øe went to Ekrin to gaine intelligence, and the King quartered at Tuxford, Laxton, and Lymonton with his whole Army, but they wanted men to fall upon any Quarters. I am ju≈øt now ≈øending a ≈ømall party to Ekrin.

Since I begunne this Letter, I heare that the King quarters this night about Welbeck and Wor≈øop and (as report gives it) he is for the North. Sir, bee plea≈øed to procure ≈øome Armes, if it be po≈øsible, and ≈øome Money, for the Country is impoveri≈øhed, and the Souldiers in great wants. Sir, I have no more, but to a≈ø≈øure you that I am

postscript.p: I be≈øeech you pre≈øent my ≈øervice to Ma≈øter Millington and excu≈øe my not writing to him.

div.head: For my Honoured Friend, Gilbert Millington, E≈øquire.

closer.signed: Your obliged friend and humble ≈øervant, John Hutchin≈øon.

div.head: For the Honourable William Lenthall E≈øq. Speaker of the Commons Hou≈øe of Parliament, the≈øe.
div.p: I Gave you an accompt the la≈øt night of my marching to Langford-hou≈øe: whether I came this day, and immediatly ≈øent them in a Summons; the Governour de≈øired I ≈øhould ≈øend two Officers to treat wtth him, and I accordingly appointed Lieutenant Colonell Hew≈øon, and Major Kel≈øey thereunto: the Treaty produced the agreement which I have here enclo≈øed to you. The Generall I heare is advanced as farre we≈øt as Columpton, and hath ≈øent ≈øome Hor≈øe and Foot to Teverton, it is earne≈øtly de≈øired that tho≈øe Foot might march up to him, it being convenient that we ≈øtay a day for our Foot that are behind and comming up. I waite your An≈øwer to my Letter la≈øt night from Wallop, I ≈øhall de≈øire that your plea≈øure may be ≈øpeeded to me, and re≈øt, Sir;

argument.p: Articles of agreement made between Sir Bartholomew Pell Knight, and Major Edmond ∆≤vedale, Commanders in chief of Langford Garri≈øon, and Liev. Col. Hew≈øon, and Major Tho. Kel≈øey on the behalf of Oliver Cromwell, Liev. Generall to Sir Thomas Fairfax Army.

div.p: FIr≈øt, That the ≈øaid Commanders in chiefe of the ≈øaid Garri≈øon ≈øhall ≈øurrender the ≈øaid Hou≈øe and Garri≈øon to the ≈øaid Lieutenant Generall Cromwell to morrow by twelve of the clock, being the eighteenth of October in≈øtant.
2 That all Armes and Amunition in the ≈øaid Garri≈øon be then delivered to the u≈øe of the Parliament without any imbe≈øiling of it.

3 That the ≈øaid Commanders in chief with 15 Gent. of the ≈øaid Garri≈øon ≈øhall march away with Hor≈øe and Armes, and the private ≈øouldiers without Armes to Oxford within ten daies, and to have a Troop of Hor≈øe for their Guard the fir≈øt day, and a Trumpet, with a Pa≈ø≈øe the re≈øt of the way.
4 That the re≈øt of the Gentlemen, not exceeding fifteene more, ≈øhall march with their Swords and Pi≈øtols, and Hor≈øes, if they can lawfully procure them.
5 That the ≈øaid Commanders in chief ≈øhall have a Cart or Waggon allowed them to carry their goods to Oxford.
6 That if any Gentleman of the ≈øaid Garri≈øon have a de≈øire to goe to any other Garri≈øon, or Army of the Kings, they ≈øhall have Pa≈ø≈øes to that purpo≈øe.
7 That the goods remaining in the ≈øaid Garri≈øon ≈øhall be delivered to the ≈øeverall Owners thereof upon demand, within two daies next following the date hereof.
8 That Lieutenant Col. Bowles and Major Fry be left Ho≈øtage untill the≈øe Articles be performed.

RE≈øolved by the Lords and Commons in Parliament A≈ø≈øembled; That on the next Lords Day publick thankes be given unto Almighty God in all the Churches and Chappels within the Lines of Communication, and on the next Lords Day come Fortnight in all other parts of the Kingdome, for the great ble≈ø≈øings and ≈øucce≈ø≈øe it hath plea≈øed God to give the Parliaments Forces in the North, neere Sherborne in York≈øhire, and in other parts of the Kingdome: And that the Mini≈øters be required to ≈øtirre up their hearts to a hearty thankfulne≈ø≈øe. And that the Lord Maior be de≈øired to give timely notice hereof to the Mini≈øters of the ≈øeverall Churches and Chappels within the Lines of Communication.
